definition: to muster large forces/to get a great number of people involved (in carrying out some task)
to rise/to flourish/to become popular/to start/to encourage/to get up/(often used in the negative) to permit or allow (dialect)/maybe (dialect)
feeling or desire to do sth/interest in sth/excitement
surname Xing
teacher/master/expert/model/army division/(old) troops/to dispatch troops
surname Shi
(of sth) to move/to set in movement/to displace/to touch/to make use of/to stir (emotions)/to alter/abbr. for 動詞|动词[dong4 ci2], verb
abbr. for 眾議院|众议院[Zhong4 yi4 yuan4], House of Representatives
many/numerous/crowd/multitude
variant of 眾|众[zhong4]

sentences.english: No wonder the whole world is launching a campaign to educate people that fat is unhealthy.
sentences.chinese: 难怪全世界都兴师动众，教育人们肥胖是不健康的。

definition: to go to war (idiom)/to make a big fuss over sth
to take great pains/to go to a lot of trouble
with great fanfare
to spread one's voice wide (idiom); wide publicity
worthwhile (often in rhetorical questions, implying not worthwhile)/also written 犯得上
to do more than is required (idiom); superfluous/gilding the lily
to make a big fuss over a minor issue (idiom)
to send punitive forces against/(fig.) to criticize violently
not worthwhile
(adverbial phrase used with verbs such as 歸|归[gui1] or 赴[fu4] etc) traveling a great distance
to plot actively (idiom)/scheming/calculating
from distant parts
very far away
to denounce/to condemn/to call to account/to punish
ostentation/a show of extravagance/grand style/red tape
lit. to go to war without just cause (idiom)/to act without justification
